linegroup.line: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see't?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: We'll wait upon your lordship.

section.title: SCENE III. The garden of the castle.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do
All my abilities in thy behalf.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Good madam, do: I warrant it grieves my husband,
As if the case were his.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: O, that's an honest fellow. Do not doubt, Cassio,
But I will have my lord and you again
As friendly as you were.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Bounteous madam,
Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,
He's never any thing but your true servant.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I know't; I thank you. You do love my lord:
You have known him long; and be you well assured
He shall in strangeness stand no further off
Than in a polite distance.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Ay, but, lady,
That policy may either last so long,
Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet,
Or breed itself so out of circumstance,
That, I being absent and my place supplied,
My general will forget my love and service.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Do not doubt that; before Emilia here
I give thee warrant of thy place: assure thee,
If I do vow a friendship, I'll perform it
To the last article: my lord shall never rest;
I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience;
His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift;
I'll intermingle every thing he does
With Cassio's suit: therefore be merry, Cassio;
For thy solicitor shall rather die
Than give thy cause away.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Madam, here comes my lord.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Madam, I'll take my leave.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, stay, and hear me speak.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Madam, not now: I am very ill at ease,
Unfit for mine own purposes.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Well, do your discretion.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ha! I like not that.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What dost thou say?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Nothing, my lord: or if--I know not what.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Cassio, my lord! No, sure, I cannot think it,
That he would steal away so guilty-like,
Seeing you coming.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I do believe 'twas he.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: How now, my lord!
I have been talking with a suitor here,
A man that languishes in your displeasure.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Who is't you mean?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio. Good my lord,
If I have any grace or power to move you,
His present reconciliation take;
For if he be not one that truly loves you,
That errs in ignorance and not in cunning,
I have no judgment in an honest face:
I prithee, call him back.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Went he hence now?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Ay, sooth; so humbled
That he hath left part of his grief with me,
To suffer with him. Good love, call him back.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Not now, sweet Desdemona; some other time.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: But shall't be shortly?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: The sooner, sweet, for you.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Shall't be to-night at supper?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: No, not to-night.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: To-morrow dinner, then?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I shall not dine at home;
I meet the captains at the citadel.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, then, to-morrow night; or Tuesday morn;
On Tuesday noon, or night; on Wednesday morn:
I prithee, name the time, but let it not
Exceed three days: in faith, he's penitent;
And yet his trespass, in our common reason--
Save that, they say, the wars must make examples
Out of their best--is not almost a fault
To incur a private cheque. When shall he come?
Tell me, Othello: I wonder in my soul,
What you would ask me, that I should deny,
Or stand so mammering on. What! Michael Cassio,
That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time,
When I have spoke of you dispraisingly,
Hath ta'en your part; to have so much to do
To bring him in! Trust me, I could do much,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Prithee, no more: let him come when he will;
I will deny thee nothing.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, this is not a boon;
'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves,
Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm,
Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit
To your own person: nay, when I have a suit
Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed,
It shall be full of poise and difficult weight
And fearful to be granted.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I will deny thee nothing:
Whereon, I do beseech thee, grant me this,
To leave me but a little to myself.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Shall I deny you? no: farewell, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Farewell, my Desdemona: I'll come to thee straight.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Emilia, come. Be as your fancies teach you;
Whate'er you be, I am obedient.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul,
But I do love thee! and when I love thee not,
Chaos is come again.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My noble lord--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What dost thou say, Iago?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Did Michael Cassio, when you woo'd my lady,
Know of your love?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: He did, from first to last: why dost thou ask?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: But for a satisfaction of my thought;
No further harm.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Why of thy thought, Iago?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, yes; and went between us very oft.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Indeed!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Indeed! ay, indeed: discern'st thou aught in that?
Is he not honest?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Honest, my lord!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Honest! ay, honest.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My lord, for aught I know.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What dost thou think?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Think, my lord!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Think, my lord!
By heaven, he echoes me,
As if there were some monster in his thought
Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something:
I heard thee say even now, thou likedst not that,
When Cassio left my wife: what didst not like?
And when I told thee he was of my counsel
In my whole course of wooing, thou criedst 'Indeed!'
And didst contract and purse thy brow together,
As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain
Some horrible conceit: if thou dost love me,
Show me thy thought.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My lord, you know I love you.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I think thou dost;
And, for I know thou'rt full of love and honesty,
And weigh'st thy words before thou givest them breath,
Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more:
For such things in a false disloyal knave
Are tricks of custom, but in a man that's just
They are close delations, working from the heart
That passion cannot rule.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: For Michael Cassio,
I dare be sworn I think that he is honest.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I think so too.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Men should be what they seem;
Or those that be not, would they might seem none!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Certain, men should be what they seem.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, then, I think Cassio's an honest man.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Nay, yet there's more in this:
I prithee, speak to me as to thy thinkings,
As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts
The worst of words.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Good my lord, pardon me:
Though I am bound to every act of duty,
I am not bound to that all slaves are free to.
Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false;
As where's that palace whereinto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? who has a breast so pure,
But some uncleanly apprehensions
Keep leets and law-days and in session sit
With meditations lawful?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago,
If thou but think'st him wrong'd and makest his ear
A stranger to thy thoughts.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I do beseech you--
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess,
As, I confess, it is my nature's plague
To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not--that your wisdom yet,
From one that so imperfectly conceits,
Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
Out of his scattering and unsure observance.
It were not for your quiet nor your good,
Nor for my manhood, honesty, or wisdom,
To let you know my thoughts.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What dost thou mean?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,
Is the immediate jewel of their souls:
Who steals my purse steals trash; 'tis something, nothing;
'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thousands:
But he that filches from me my good name
Robs me of that which not enriches him
And makes me poor indeed.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: By heaven, I'll know thy thoughts.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand;
Nor shall not, whilst 'tis in my custody.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Ha!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: O, beware, my lord, of jealousy;
It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock
The meat it feeds on; that cuckold lives in bliss
Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger;
But, O, what damned minutes tells he o'er
Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O misery!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Poor and content is rich and rich enough,
But riches fineless is as poor as winter
To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good heaven, the souls of all my tribe defend
From jealousy!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Why, why is this?
Think'st thou I'ld make a lie of jealousy,
To follow still the changes of the moon
With fresh suspicions? No; to be once in doubt
Is once to be resolved: exchange me for a goat,
When I shall turn the business of my soul
To such exsufflicate and blown surmises,
Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous
To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
Is free of speech, sings, plays and dances well;
Where virtue is, these are more virtuous:
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt;
For she had eyes, and chose me. No, Iago;
I'll see before I doubt; when I doubt, prove;
And on the proof, there is no more but this,--
Away at once with love or jealousy!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I am glad of it; for now I shall have reason
To show the love and duty that I bear you
With franker spirit: therefore, as I am bound,
Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof.
Look to your wife; observe her well with Cassio;
Wear your eye thus, not jealous nor secure:
I would not have your free and noble nature,
Out of self-bounty, be abused; look to't:
I know our country disposition well;
In Venice they do let heaven see the pranks
They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience
Is not to leave't undone, but keep't unknown.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Dost thou say so?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: She did deceive her father, marrying you;
And when she seem'd to shake and fear your looks,
She loved them most.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: And so she did.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, go to then;
She that, so young, could give out such a seeming,
To seal her father's eyes up close as oak-
He thought 'twas witchcraft--but I am much to blame;
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I am bound to thee for ever.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I see this hath a little dash'd your spirits.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Not a jot, not a jot.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I' faith, I fear it has.
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from my love. But I do see you're moved:
I am to pray you not to strain my speech
To grosser issues nor to larger reach
Than to suspicion.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I will not.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Should you do so, my lord,
My speech should fall into such vile success
As my thoughts aim not at. Cassio's my worthy friend--
My lord, I see you're moved.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: No, not much moved:
I do not think but Desdemona's honest.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Long live she so! and long live you to think so!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: And yet, how nature erring from itself,--

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ay, there's the point: as--to be bold with you--
Not to affect many proposed matches
Of her own clime, complexion, and degree,
Whereto we see in all things nature tends--
Foh! one may smell in such a will most rank,
Foul disproportion thoughts unnatural.
But pardon me; I do not in position
Distinctly speak of her; though I may fear
Her will, recoiling to her better judgment,
May fall to match you with her country forms
And happily repent.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Farewell, farewell:
If more thou dost perceive, let me know more;
Set on thy wife to observe: leave me, Iago:

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Going My lord, I take my leave.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Why did I marry? This honest creature doubtless
Sees and knows more, much more, than he unfolds.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Returning My lord, I would I might entreat
your honour
To scan this thing no further; leave it to time:
Though it be fit that Cassio have his place,
For sure, he fills it up with great ability,
Yet, if you please to hold him off awhile,
You shall by that perceive him and his means:
Note, if your lady strain his entertainment
With any strong or vehement importunity;
Much will be seen in that. In the mean time,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears--
As worthy cause I have to fear I am--
And hold her free, I do beseech your honour.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Fear not my government.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I once more take my leave.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: This fellow's of exceeding honesty,
And knows all qualities, with a learned spirit,
Of human dealings. If I do prove her haggard,
Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings,
I'ld whistle her off and let her down the wind,
To pray at fortune. Haply, for I am black
And have not those soft parts of conversation
That chamberers have, or for I am declined
Into the vale of years,--yet that's not much--
She's gone. I am abused; and my relief
Must be to loathe her. O curse of marriage,
That we can call these delicate creatures ours,
And not their appetites! I had rather be a toad,
And live upon the vapour of a dungeon,
Than keep a corner in the thing I love
For others' uses. Yet, 'tis the plague of great ones;
Prerogatived are they less than the base;
'Tis destiny unshunnable, like death:
Even then this forked plague is fated to us
When we do quicken. Desdemona comes:
If she be false, O, then heaven mocks itself!
I'll not believe't.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: How now, my dear Othello!
Your dinner, and the generous islanders
By you invited, do attend your presence.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I am to blame.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why do you speak so faintly?
Are you not well?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I have a pain upon my forehead here.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: 'Faith, that's with watching; 'twill away again:
Let me but bind it hard, within this hour
It will be well.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Your napkin is too little:
linegroup.para: He puts the handkerchief from him; and it drops
linegroup.line: Let it alone. Come, I'll go in with you.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I am very sorry that you are not well.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I am glad I have found this napkin:
This was her first remembrance from the Moor:
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
Woo'd me to steal it; but she so loves the token,
For he conjured her she should ever keep it,
That she reserves it evermore about her
To kiss and talk to. I'll have the work ta'en out,
And give't Iago: what he will do with it
Heaven knows, not I;
I nothing but to please his fantasy.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: How now! what do you here alone?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Do not you chide; I have a thing for you.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: A thing for me? it is a common thing--

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Ha!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: To have a foolish wife.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: O, is that all? What will you give me now
For the same handkerchief?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What handkerchief?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: What handkerchief?
Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona;
That which so often you did bid me steal.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Hast stol'n it from her?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: No, 'faith; she let it drop by negligence.
And, to the advantage, I, being here, took't up.
Look, here it is.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: A good wench; give it me.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: What will you do with 't, that you have been
so earnest
To have me filch it?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Snatching it Why, what's that to you?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give't me again: poor lady, she'll run mad
When she shall lack it.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Be not acknown on 't; I have use for it.
Go, leave me.
I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin,
And let him find it. Trifles light as air
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ: this may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits are, in their natures, poisons.
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,
But with a little act upon the blood.
Burn like the mines of Sulphur. I did say so:
Look, where he comes!
Not poppy, nor mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou owedst yesterday.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Ha! ha! false to me?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, how now, general! no more of that.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Avaunt! be gone! thou hast set me on the rack:
I swear 'tis better to be much abused
Than but to know't a little.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: How now, my lord!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What sense had I of her stol'n hours of lust?
I saw't not, thought it not, it harm'd not me:
I slept the next night well, was free and merry;
I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips:
He that is robb'd, not wanting what is stol'n,
Let him not know't, and he's not robb'd at all.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I am sorry to hear this.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I had been happy, if the general camp,
Pioners and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known. O, now, for ever
Farewell the tranquil mind! farewell content!
Farewell the plumed troop, and the big wars,
That make ambition virtue! O, farewell!
Farewell the neighing steed, and the shrill trump,
The spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife,
The royal banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp and circumstance of glorious war!
And, O you mortal engines, whose rude throats
The immortal Jove's dead clamours counterfeit,
Farewell! Othello's occupation's gone!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Is't possible, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore,
Be sure of it; give me the ocular proof:
Or by the worth of man's eternal soul,
Thou hadst been better have been born a dog
Than answer my waked wrath!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Is't come to this?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Make me to see't; or, at the least, so prove it,
That the probation bear no hinge nor loop
To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My noble lord,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: If thou dost slander her and torture me,
Never pray more; abandon all remorse;
On horror's head horrors accumulate;
Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed;
For nothing canst thou to damnation add
Greater than that.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: O grace! O heaven forgive me!
Are you a man? have you a soul or sense?
God be wi' you; take mine office. O wretched fool.
That livest to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest is not safe.
I thank you for this profit; and from hence
I'll love no friend, sith love breeds such offence.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Nay, stay: thou shouldst be honest.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I should be wise, for honesty's a fool
And loses that it works for.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: By the world,
I think my wife be honest and think she is not;
I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
I'll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh
As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black
As mine own face. If there be cords, or knives,
Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,
I'll not endure it. Would I were satisfied!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion:
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Would! nay, I will.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: And may: but, how? how satisfied, my lord?
Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on--
Behold her topp'd?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Death and damnation! O!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that prospect: damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own! What then? how then?
What shall I say? Where's satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,
As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross
As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances,
Which lead directly to the door of truth,
Will give you satisfaction, you may have't.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Give me a living reason she's disloyal.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I do not like the office:
But, sith I am enter'd in this cause so far,
Prick'd to't by foolish honesty and love,
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately;
And, being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep.
There are a kind of men so loose of soul,
That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs:
One of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say 'Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our loves;'
And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,
Cry 'O sweet creature!' and then kiss me hard,
As if he pluck'd up kisses by the roots
That grew upon my lips: then laid his leg
Over my thigh, and sigh'd, and kiss'd; and then
Cried 'Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!'

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O monstrous! monstrous!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Nay, this was but his dream.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: But this denoted a foregone conclusion:
'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I'll tear her all to pieces.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Nay, but be wise: yet we see nothing done;
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I know not that; but such a handkerchief--
I am sure it was your wife's--did I to-day
See Cassio wipe his beard with.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: If it be that--

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: If it be that, or any that was hers,
It speaks against her with the other proofs.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Now do I see 'tis true. Look here, Iago;
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
'Tis gone.
Arise, black vengeance, from thy hollow cell!
Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
For 'tis of aspics' tongues!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Yet be content.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, blood, blood, blood!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Patience, I say; your mind perhaps may change.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Never, Iago: Like to the Pontic sea,
Whose icy current and compulsive course
Ne'er feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on
To the Propontic and the Hellespont,
Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace,
Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love,
Till that a capable and wide revenge
Swallow them up. Now, by yond marble heaven,
In the due reverence of a sacred vow
I here engage my words.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Do not rise yet.
Witness, you ever-burning lights above,
You elements that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wrong'd Othello's service! Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I greet thy love,
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to't:
Within these three days let me hear thee say
That Cassio's not alive.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My friend is dead; 'tis done at your request:
But let her live.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her!
Come, go with me apart; I will withdraw,
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I am your own for ever.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I dare not say he lies any where.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, man?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: He's a soldier, and for one to say a soldier lies,
is stabbing.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Go to: where lodges he?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: To tell you where he lodges, is to tell you where I lie.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Can any thing be made of this?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a
lodging and say he lies here or he lies there, were
to lie in mine own throat.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Can you inquire him out, and be edified by report?

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: I will catechise the world for him; that is, make
questions, and by them answer.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Seek him, bid him come hither: tell him I have
moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.

linegroup.speaker: Clown
linegroup.line: To do this is within the compass of man's wit: and
therefore I will attempt the doing it.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I know not, madam.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of crusadoes: and, but my noble Moor
Is true of mind and made of no such baseness
As jealous creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill thinking.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Is he not jealous?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Who, he? I think the sun where he was born
Drew all such humours from him.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Look, where he comes.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I will not leave him now till Cassio
Be call'd to him.
How is't with you, my lord

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Well, my good lady.
O, hardness to dissemble!--
How do you, Desdemona?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Well, my good lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Give me your hand: this hand is moist, my lady.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: It yet hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart:
Hot, hot, and moist: this hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer,
Much castigation, exercise devout;
For here's a young and sweating devil here,
That commonly rebels. 'Tis a good hand,
A frank one.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: You may, indeed, say so;
For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: A liberal hand: the hearts of old gave hands;
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I cannot speak of this. Come now, your promise.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What promise, chuck?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me;
Lend me thy handkerchief.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Here, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: That which I gave you.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I have it not about me.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Not?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: No, indeed, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: That is a fault.
That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give;
She was a charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people: she told her, while
she kept it,
'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father
Entirely to her love, but if she lost it
Or made gift of it, my father's eye
Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies: she, dying, gave it me;
And bid me, when my fate would have me wive,
To give it her. I did so: and take heed on't;
Make it a darling like your precious eye;
To lose't or give't away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Is't possible?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: 'Tis true: there's magic in the web of it:
A sibyl, that had number'd in the world
The sun to course two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury sew'd the work;
The worms were hallow'd that did breed the silk;
And it was dyed in mummy which the skilful
Conserved of maidens' hearts.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Indeed! is't true?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Most veritable; therefore look to't well.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Then would to God that I had never seen't!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Ha! wherefore?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why do you speak so startingly and rash?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Is't lost? is't gone? speak, is it out
o' the way?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Heaven bless us!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Say you?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: It is not lost; but what an if it were?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: How!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I say, it is not lost.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Fetch't, let me see't.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now.
This is a trick to put me from my suit:
Pray you, let Cassio be received again.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Fetch me the handkerchief: my mind misgives.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Come, come;
You'll never meet a more sufficient man.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: The handkerchief!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I pray, talk me of Cassio.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: The handkerchief!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shared dangers with you,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: The handkerchief!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: In sooth, you are to blame.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Away!

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Is not this man jealous?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I ne'er saw this before.
Sure, there's some wonder in this handkerchief:
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but stomachs, and we all but food;
To eat us hungerly, and when they are full,
They belch us. Look you, Cassio and my husband!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: There is no other way; 'tis she must do't:
And, lo, the happiness! go, and importune her.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: How now, good Cassio! what's the news with you?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love
Whom I with all the office of my heart
Entirely honour: I would not be delay'd.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purposed merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit;
So shall I clothe me in a forced content,
And shut myself up in some other course,
To fortune's alms.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio!
My advocation is not now in tune;
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him,
Were he in favour as in humour alter'd.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! you must awhile be patient:
What I can do I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare: let that suffice you.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Is my lord angry?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: He went hence but now,
And certainly in strange unquietness.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon,
When it hath blown his ranks into the air,
And, like the devil, from his very arm
Puff'd his own brother:--and can he be angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him:
There's matter in't indeed, if he be angry.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I prithee, do so.
Something, sure, of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatch'd practise
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit: and in such cases
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so;
For let our finger ache, and it indues
Our other healthful members even to that sense
Of pain: nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observances
As fit the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia,
I was, unhandsome warrior as I am,
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find I had suborn'd the witness,
And he's indicted falsely.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Pray heaven it be state-matters, as you think,
And no conception nor no jealous toy
Concerning you.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Alas the day! I never gave him cause.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: But jealous souls will not be answer'd so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they are jealous: 'tis a monster
Begot upon itself, born on itself.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind!

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Lady, amen.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I will go seek him. Cassio, walk hereabout:
If I do find him fit, I'll move your suit
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: I humbly thank your ladyship.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: Save you, friend Cassio!

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: What make you from home?
How is it with you, my most fair Bianca?
I' faith, sweet love, I was coming to your house.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
What, keep a week away? seven days and nights?
Eight score eight hours? and lovers' absent hours,
More tedious than the dial eight score times?
O weary reckoning!

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Pardon me, Bianca:
I have this while with leaden thoughts been press'd:
But I shall, in a more continuate time,
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca,
Take me this work out.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend:
To the felt absence now I feel a cause:
Is't come to this? Well, well.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Go to, woman!
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance:
No, in good troth, Bianca.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: Why, whose is it?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: I know not, sweet: I found it in my chamber.
I like the work well: ere it be demanded--
As like enough it will--I'ld have it copied:
Take it, and do't; and leave me for this time.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: Leave you! wherefore?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: I do attend here on the general;
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me woman'd.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: Why, I pray you?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Not that I love you not.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: But that you do not love me.
I pray you, bring me on the way a little,
And say if I shall see you soon at night.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: 'Tis but a little way that I can bring you;
For I attend here: but I'll see you soon.

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: 'Tis very good; I must be circumstanced.

section.title: SCENE I. Cyprus. Before the castle.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Will you think so?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Think so, Iago!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What,
To kiss in private?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: An unauthorized kiss.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour or more, not meaning any harm?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: So they do nothing, 'tis a venial slip:
But if I give my wife a handkerchief,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What then?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, then, 'tis hers, my lord; and, being hers,
She may, I think, bestow't on any man.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: She is protectress of her honour too:
May she give that?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Her honour is an essence that's not seen;
They have it very oft that have it not:
But, for the handkerchief,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Thou said'st, it comes o'er my memory,
As doth the raven o'er the infected house,
Boding to all--he had my handkerchief.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ay, what of that?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: That's not so good now.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What,
If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say,--as knaves be such abroad,
Who having, by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Hath he said any thing?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: He hath, my lord; but be you well assured,
No more than he'll unswear.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What hath he said?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, that he did--I know not what he did.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What? what?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Lie--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: With her?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: With her, on her; what you will.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her, when
they belie her. Lie with her! that's fulsome.
--Handkerchief--confessions--handkerchief!--To
confess, and be hanged for his labour;--first, to be
hanged, and then to confess.--I tremble at it.
Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing
passion without some instruction. It is not words
that shake me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips.
--Is't possible?--Confess--handkerchief!--O devil!--

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Work on,
My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught;
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,
All guiltless, meet reproach. What, ho! my lord!
My lord, I say! Othello!
How now, Cassio!

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: What's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy:
This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Rub him about the temples.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: No, forbear;
The lethargy must have his quiet course:
If not, he foams at mouth and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight: when he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you.
How is it, general? have you not hurt your head?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Dost thou mock me?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I mock you! no, by heaven.
Would you would bear your fortune like a man!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: A horned man's a monster and a beast.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: There's many a beast then in a populous city,
And many a civil monster.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Did he confess it?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Good sir, be a man;
Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked
May draw with you: there's millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better.
O, 'tis the spite of hell, the fiend's arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste! No, let me know;
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, thou art wise; 'tis certain.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Stand you awhile apart;
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief--
A passion most unsuiting such a man--
Cassio came hither: I shifted him away,
And laid good 'scuse upon your ecstasy,
Bade him anon return and here speak with me;
The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns,
That dwell in every region of his face;
For I will make him tell the tale anew,
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife:
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience;
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Dost thou hear, Iago?
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But--dost thou hear?--most bloody.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: That's not amiss;
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A housewife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a creature
That dotes on Cassio; as 'tis the strumpet's plague
To beguile many and be beguiled by one:
He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes:
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad;
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures and light behavior,
Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: The worser that you give me the addition
Whose want even kills me.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on't.
Now, if this suit lay in Bianco's power,
How quickly should you speed!

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Alas, poor caitiff!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Look, how he laughs already!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I never knew woman love man so.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Alas, poor rogue! I think, i' faith, she loves me.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Do you hear, Cassio?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Now he importunes him
To tell it o'er: go to; well said, well said.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: She gives it out that you shall marry hey:
Do you intend it?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Ha, ha, ha!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Do you triumph, Roman? do you triumph?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: I marry her! what? a customer! Prithee, bear some
charity to my wit: do not think it so unwholesome.
Ha, ha, ha!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: So, so, so, so: they laugh that win.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, the cry goes that you shall marry her.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Prithee, say true.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I am a very villain else.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Have you scored me? Well.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: This is the monkey's own giving out: she is
persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and
flattery, not out of my promise.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Iago beckons me; now he begins the story.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: She was here even now; she haunts me in every place.
I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with
certain Venetians; and thither comes the bauble,
and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Crying 'O dear Cassio!' as it were: his gesture
imports it.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: So hangs, and lolls, and weeps upon me; so hales,
and pulls me: ha, ha, ha!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber. O,
I see that nose of yours, but not that dog I shall
throw it to.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Well, I must leave her company.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Before me! look, where she comes.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: 'Tis such another fitchew! marry a perfumed one.
What do you mean by this haunting of me?

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you
mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now?
I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the
work?--A likely piece of work, that you should find
it in your chamber, and not know who left it there!
This is some minx's token, and I must take out the
work? There; give it your hobby-horse: wheresoever
you had it, I'll take out no work on't.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: How now, my sweet Bianca! how now! how now!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

linegroup.speaker: BIANCA
linegroup.line: An you'll come to supper to-night, you may; an you
will not, come when you are next prepared for.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: After her, after her.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, I must; she'll rail in the street else.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Will you sup there?

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, I intend so.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Well, I may chance to see you; for I would very fain
speak with you.

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: Prithee, come; will you?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Go to; say no more.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Advancing How shall I murder him, Iago?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O Iago!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: And did you see the handkerchief?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Was that mine?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Yours by this hand: and to see how he prizes the
foolish woman your wife! she gave it him, and he
hath given it his whore.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I would have him nine years a-killing.
A fine woman! a fair woman! a sweet woman!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Nay, you must forget that.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Ay, let her rot, and perish, and be damned to-night;
for she shall not live: no, my heart is turned to
stone; I strike it, and it hurts my hand. O, the
world hath not a sweeter creature: she might lie by
an emperor's side and command him tasks.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Nay, that's not your way.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Hang her! I do but say what she is: so delicate
with her needle: an admirable musician: O! she
will sing the savageness out of a bear: of so high
and plenteous wit and invention:--

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: She's the worse for all this.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, a thousand thousand times: and then, of so
gentle a condition!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ay, too gentle.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Nay, that's certain: but yet the pity of it, Iago!
O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her
patent to offend; for, if it touch not you, it comes
near nobody.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I will chop her into messes: cuckold me!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: O, 'tis foul in her.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: With mine officer!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: That's fouler.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Get me some poison, Iago; this night: I'll not
expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty
unprovide my mind again: this night, Iago.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Do it not with poison, strangle her in her bed, even
the bed she hath contaminated.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Good, good: the justice of it pleases: very good.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker: you
shall hear more by midnight.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Excellent good.
What trumpet is that same?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Something from Venice, sure. 'Tis Lodovico
Come from the duke: and, see, your wife is with him.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Save you, worthy general!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: With all my heart, sir.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I am very glad to see you, signior
Welcome to Cyprus.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Lives, sir.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Cousin, there's fall'n between him and my lord
An unkind breach: but you shall make all well.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Are you sure of that?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Reads 'This fail you not to do, as you will--'

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: He did not call; he's busy in the paper.
Is there division 'twixt my lord and Cassio?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: A most unhappy one: I would do much
To atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Fire and brimstone!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Are you wise?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: What, is he angry?

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: May be the letter moved him;
For, as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his government.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Trust me, I am glad on't.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Indeed!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I am glad to see you mad.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Why, sweet Othello,--

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Striking her Devil!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I have not deserved this.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw't: 'tis very much:
Make her amends; she weeps.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O devil, devil!
If that the earth could teem with woman's tears,
Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.
Out of my sight!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I will not stay to offend you.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Truly, an obedient lady:
I do beseech your lordship, call her back.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Mistress!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What would you with her, sir?

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Who, I, my lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Ay; you did wish that I would make her turn:
Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep;
And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
Very obedient. Proceed you in your tears.
Concerning this, sir,--O well-painted passion!--
I am commanded home. Get you away;
I'll send for you anon. Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice. Hence, avaunt!
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight,
I do entreat that we may sup together:
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.--Goats and monkeys!

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? whose solid virtue
The shot of accident, nor dart of chance,
Could neither graze nor pierce?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: He is much changed.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Are his wits safe? is he not light of brain?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: He's that he is: I may not breathe my censure
What he might be: if what he might he is not,
I would to heaven he were!

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: What, strike his wife!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst!

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood,
And new-create this fault?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech: do but go after,
And mark how he continues.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.

section.title: SCENE II. A room in the castle.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: You have seen nothing then?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
Each syllable that breath made up between them.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What, did they never whisper?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Never, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Nor send you out o' the way?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Never.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Never, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: That's strange.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other,
Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse!
For, if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There's no man happy; the purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Bid her come hither: go.
She says enough; yet she's a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore,
A closet lock and key of villanous secrets
And yet she'll kneel and pray; I have seen her do't.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord, what is your will?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Pray, chuck, come hither.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: What is your pleasure?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Let me see your eyes;
Look in my face.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: What horrible fancy's this?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: To EMILIA Some of your function, mistress;
Leave procreants alone and shut the door;
Cough, or cry 'hem,' if any body come:
Your mystery, your mystery: nay, dispatch.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Upon my knees, what doth your speech import?
I understand a fury in your words.
But not the words.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Why, what art thou?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Your wife, my lord; your true
And loyal wife.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Come, swear it, damn thyself
Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to seize thee: therefore be double damn'd:
Swear thou art honest.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Heaven doth truly know it.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: To whom, my lord? with whom? how am I false?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O Desdemona! away! away! away!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me: If you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction; had they rain'd
All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head.
Steep'd me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience: but, alas, to make me
A fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too; well, very well:
But there, where I have garner'd up my heart,
Where either I must live, or bear no life;
The fountain from the which my current runs,
Or else dries up; to be discarded thence!
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipp'd cherubin,--
Ay, there, look grim as hell!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, ay; as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed,
Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet
That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst
ne'er been born!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write 'whore' upon? What committed!
Committed! O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks,
That would to cinders burn up modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed!
Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks,
The bawdy wind that kisses all it meets
Is hush'd within the hollow mine of earth,
And will not hear it. What committed!
Impudent strumpet!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: By heaven, you do me wrong.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Are you not a strumpet?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: No, as I am a Christian:
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: What, not a whore?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: No, as I shall be saved.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Is't possible?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: O, heaven forgive us!

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: I cry you mercy, then:
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello.
You, mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keep the gate of hell!
You, you, ay, you!
We have done our course; there's money for your pains:
I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do you, madam? how do you, my good lady?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: 'Faith, half asleep.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: With who?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Why, with my lord, madam.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Who is thy lord?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: He that is yours, sweet lady.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I have none: do not talk to me, Emilia;
I cannot weep; nor answer have I none,
But what should go by water. Prithee, tonight
Lay on my bed my wedding sheets: remember;
And call thy husband hither.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Here's a change indeed!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: 'Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
How have I been behaved, that he might stick
The small'st opinion on my least misuse?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What is your pleasure, madam?
How is't with you?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks:
He might have chid me so; for, in good faith,
I am a child to chiding.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What's the matter, lady?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her.
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her,
As true hearts cannot bear.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Am I that name, Iago?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What name, fair lady?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Such as she says my lord did say I was.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: He call'd her whore: a beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callat.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why did he so?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I do not know; I am sure I am none such.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Hath she forsook so many noble matches,
Her father and her country and her friends,
To be call'd whore? would it not make one weep?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: It is my wretched fortune.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Beshrew him for't!
How comes this trick upon him?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Nay, heaven doth know.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Fie, there is no such man; it is impossible.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: A halter pardon him! and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place? what time? what form? what likelihood?
The Moor's abused by some most villanous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heaven, that such companions thou'ldst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to the west!

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Speak within door.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: O, fie upon them! Some such squire he was
That turn'd your wit the seamy side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: You are a fool; go to.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: O good Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him; for, by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
Delighted them in any other form;
Or that I do not yet, and ever did.
And ever will--though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement--love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much;
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say 'whore:'
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I pray you, be content; 'tis but his humour:
The business of the state does him offence,
And he does chide with you.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: If 'twere no other--

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: 'Tis but so, I warrant.
Hark, how these instruments summon to supper!
The messengers of Venice stay the meat;
Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.
How now, Roderigo!

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: I do not find that thou dealest justly with me.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: What in the contrary?

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Every day thou daffest me with some device, Iago;
and rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from me
all conveniency than suppliest me with the least
advantage of hope. I will indeed no longer endure
it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what
already I have foolishly suffered.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: 'Faith, I have heard too much, for your words and
performances are no kin together.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: You charge me most unjustly.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out of
my means. The jewels you have had from me to
deliver to Desdemona would half have corrupted a
votarist: you have told me she hath received them
and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden
respect and acquaintance, but I find none.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Well; go to; very well.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Very well! go to! I cannot go to, man; nor 'tis
not very well: nay, I think it is scurvy, and begin
to find myself fobbed in it.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Very well.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: I tell you 'tis not very well. I will make myself
known to Desdemona: if she will return me my
jewels, I will give over my suit and repent my
unlawful solicitation; if not, assure yourself I
will seek satisfaction of you.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: You have said now.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, now I see there's mettle in thee, and even from
this instant to build on thee a better opinion than
ever before. Give me thy hand, Roderigo: thou hast
taken against me a most just exception; but yet, I
protest, I have dealt most directly in thy affair.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: It hath not appeared.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your
suspicion is not without wit and judgment. But,
Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I
have greater reason to believe now than ever, I mean
purpose, courage and valour, this night show it: if
thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona,
take me from this world with treachery and devise
engines for my life.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Well, what is it? is it within reason and compass?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice
to depute Cassio in Othello's place.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Is that true? why, then Othello and Desdemona
return again to Venice.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: O, no; he goes into Mauritania and takes away with
him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be
lingered here by some accident: wherein none can be
so determinate as the removing of Cassio.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: How do you mean, removing of him?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's place;
knocking out his brains.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: And that you would have me to do?

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.
He sups to-night with a harlotry, and thither will I
go to him: he knows not yet of his horrorable
fortune. If you will watch his going thence, which
I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one,
you may take him at your pleasure: I will be near
to second your attempt, and he shall fall between
us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with
me; I will show you such a necessity in his death
that you shall think yourself bound to put it on
him. It is now high suppertime, and the night grows
to waste: about it.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: I will hear further reason for this.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: And you shall be satisfied.

section.title: SCENE III. Another room In the castle.
section.para: Enter OTHELLO, LODOVICO, DESDEMONA, EMILIA and Attendants

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: O, pardon me: 'twill do me good to walk.

linegroup.speaker: LODOVICO
linegroup.line: Madam, good night; I humbly thank your ladyship.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Your honour is most welcome.

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Will you walk, sir?
O,--Desdemona,--

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My lord?

linegroup.speaker: OTHELLO
linegroup.line: Get you to bed on the instant; I will be returned
forthwith: dismiss your attendant there: look it be done.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I will, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: How goes it now? he looks gentler than he did.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: He says he will return incontinent:
He hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bade me to dismiss you.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Dismiss me!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: It was his bidding: therefore, good Emilia,.
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu:
We must not now displease him.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I would you had never seen him!

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: So would not I my love doth so approve him,
That even his stubbornness, his cheques, his frowns--
Prithee, unpin me,--have grace and favour in them.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: All's one. Good faith, how foolish are our minds!
If I do die before thee prithee, shroud me
In one of those same sheets.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Come, come you talk.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: My mother had a maid call'd Barbara:
She was in love, and he she loved proved mad
And did forsake her: she had a song of 'willow;'
An old thing 'twas, but it express'd her fortune,
And she died singing it: that song to-night
Will not go from my mind; I have much to do,
But to go hang my head all at one side,
And sing it like poor Barbara. Prithee, dispatch.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Shall I go fetch your night-gown?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: No, unpin me here.
This Lodovico is a proper man.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: A very handsome man.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: He speaks well.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot
to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Singing The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
Sing all a green willow:
Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
Sing willow, willow, willow:
The fresh streams ran by her, and murmur'd her moans;
Sing willow, willow, willow;
Her salt tears fell from her, and soften'd the stones;
Lay by these:--
Sing willow, willow, willow;
Prithee, hie thee; he'll come anon:--
Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Let nobody blame him; his scorn I approve,-
Nay, that's not next.--Hark! who is't that knocks?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: It's the wind.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Singing I call'd my love false love; but what
said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow:
If I court moe women, you'll couch with moe men!
So, get thee gone; good night Ate eyes do itch;
Doth that bode weeping?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: 'Tis neither here nor there.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think,--tell me, Emilia,--
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: There be some such, no question.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Why, would not you?

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: No, by this heavenly light!

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Nor I neither by this heavenly light;
I might do't as well i' the dark.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: The world's a huge thing: it is a great price.
For a small vice.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: In troth, I think I should; and undo't when I had
done. Marry, I would not do such a thing for a
joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for
gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty
exhibition; but for the whole world,--why, who would
not make her husband a cuckold to make him a
monarch? I should venture purgatory for't.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong
For the whole world.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' the world: and
having the world for your labour, tis a wrong in your
own world, and you might quickly make it right.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: I do not think there is any such woman.

linegroup.speaker: EMILIA
linegroup.line: Yes, a dozen; and as many to the vantage as would
store the world they played for.
But I do think it is their husbands' faults
If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties,
And pour our treasures into foreign laps,
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us; or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite;
Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them: they see and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is: and doth affection breed it?
I think it doth: is't frailty that thus errs?
It is so too: and have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well: else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.

linegroup.speaker: DESDEMONA
linegroup.line: Good night, good night: heaven me such uses send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!

section.title: SCENE I. Cyprus. A street.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Here, stand behind this bulk; straight will he come:
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home:
Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow:
It makes us, or it mars us; think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: Be near at hand; I may miscarry in't.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: Here, at thy hand: be bold, and take thy stand.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: I have no great devotion to the deed;
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons:
'Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword: he dies.

linegroup.speaker: IAGO
linegroup.line: I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain: live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobb'd from him,
As gifts to Desdemona;
It must not be: if Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly; and, besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril:
No, he must die. But so: I hear him coming.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
linegroup.line: I know his gait, 'tis he.--Villain, thou diest!

linegroup.speaker: CASSIO
linegroup.line: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou know'st
I will make proof of thine.

linegroup.speaker: RODERIGO
